citations.narrative:
The dates of disposition are missing from the Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7005) for three
kittens; 24-9, 24-6 and 24-13. Disposition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of
animals still at the facility during inspection and to properly trace their movements. Each dealer, other than operators of
auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or
forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning each dog or cat purchased or otherwise
acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported,
euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born of any
animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control. The facility must ensure all required information is
properly and accurately documented at all times.
To be corrected by: 23-August-2024.

The facility is missing the disposition information for 10 domestic chickens. The facility has been removing chickens but
has not kept a record of dates of disposition or the name and address of where the birds went. Disposition information is
necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals still at the facility during inspection and to properly
trace their movements.
Each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning animals, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control. These
records shall include the name and address of the person from whom the animals were acquired from, the USDA license
or registration number of the person if they are licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and state and the
driver's license number and state of the person if they are not licensed under the Act, the name and address of the person
to whom an animal was sold or given to, the date of the purchase, acquisition, sale or disposal of the animal, the species
of the animal, and the number of animals in the shipment.
The facility must maintain a record of disposition for the animals and ensure all required information is properly and
accurately documented at all times.

The facility's employee is not readily identifiable at the time of inspection, they were wearing a non-facility affiliated t-shirt.
The inspector was only able to figure out who the employee was when they saw the employee selling food items for the
animals. The facility representative conducting the inspection stated they have employee name tags or buttons but none
were available for the staff member on the day of the inspection. Employees that are not readily identifiable make it
difficult for the public to find if an concern of human or animal safety arises. A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily
identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public contact.
The facility did not have adequate staffing to supervise public contact with the animals. One staff member was
responsible for selling food items for the animals, complete daily cleaning and supervise public interactions between 30+
members of the public. The public can enter the chicken/duck enclosure and feed/touch over and through fences housing
the other 28 animals. Several animal enclosures are out of the view of the building where the employee was selling food
items. Children were seen in the poultry pen chasing chickens, picking them up and holding them. The inspector notified
the employee that this was taking place and they addressed the children. The employee left to do another task and the
children continued to chase the chickens. Failure to supervise public interactions may result in injury to the animals or the
public. During periods of public interaction, a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee must be
present at all times to ensure the public’s safety as well as the well-being of the animals. The facility must have enough
employees to supervise all public contact with animals at all times.
Both to be corrected by: 23-August-2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
